channel.title: NPR Topics: Education
channel.description: We've been to school. We know how education works. Right? In fact, many aspects of learning — in homes, at schools, at work and elsewhere — are evolving rapidly, along with our understanding of learning. Join us as we explore how learning happens.

item.title: Why so many public schools are closing
item.description: Across the country, districts are reckoning with school closures. At many schools, enrollment is low, and funding depends on students. We look at public education and what's leading to low enrollment.
item.content:encoded: Across the country, districts are reckoning with school closures. At many schools, enrollment is low, and funding depends on students. We look at public education and what's leading to low enrollment.
item.dc:creator: Wailin Wong

item.title: College costs have risen dramatically in the last 20 years. Here's why
item.description: It's no secret that going to college can be very expensive, with tuition costs rising faster than financial aid. But what's causing that price tag to rise so quickly?

item.title: Trump administration shares plan to dismantle more of the Department of Education
item.description: The Trump administration unveiled a sweeping plan to dismantle large swaths of the Department of Education, shifting some of its key work to other agencies.

item.title: Faculty, advocates react to Texas A&M University's new race and gender approval system
item.description: The new Texas A&M University System, which requires professors to obtain approval from the school president to discuss certain race and gender topics, has been met with opposition from faculty and freedom of speech advocates.

item.title: Are college students getting too many A's?
item.description: Harvard University officials have recently raised the alarm on grade inflation. More than 60% of grades awarded to students have been A's. That's up 25% from two decades ago.
